pullrequest.title: Refactoring the cmake scripts to use ignition-cmake

pull_request.title: Refactoring the cmake scripts to use ignition-cmake

pullrequest.title: Refactoring the cmake scripts to use ignition-cmake

content.raw:
I should be more careful when trying to reply to comments using my phone. I meant for that earlier to reply to go to [this](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/69/refactoring-the-cmake-scripts-to-use/diff#comment-49915441) comment.

I see what you mean about the ordering here. That's kind of a silly thing for Clang to do. Your suggestion would work, but I think the safest thing to do would be `#if defined(__GNUC__) && !defined(__clang__)` to make it explicit that there's a possibility of ambiguity.
content.html:
I should be more careful when trying to reply to comments using my phone. I meant for that earlier to reply to go to this comment.

I see what you mean about the ordering here. That's kind of a silly thing for Clang to do. Your suggestion would work, but I think the safest thing to do would be #if defined(__GNUC__) && !defined(__clang__) to make it explicit that there's a possibility of ambiguity.

pull_request.title: Refactoring the cmake scripts to use ignition-cmake

pullrequest.title: Refactoring the cmake scripts to use ignition-cmake

content.raw:
thanks, I'll start some more jenkins jobs

I think we should also reverse the order of this logic:

~~~
#if defined __GNUC__
...
#elif defined __clang__
...
~~~

should probably be:

~~~
#if defined __clang__
...
#elif defined __GNUC__
...
~~~
content.html:
thanks, I'll start some more jenkins jobs

I think we should also reverse the order of this logic:

#if defined __GNUC__
...
#elif defined __clang__
...

should probably be:

#if defined __clang__
...
#elif defined __GNUC__
...

content.raw: The fix for it is simple, I just overlooked this detail last night. I can just do the same thing for the ending macro that I did for the beginning macro. We create a token-specific ending macro which is blank for warnings that don't exist for the current compiler.
content.html: The fix for it is simple, I just overlooked this detail last night. I can just do the same thing for the ending macro that I did for the beginning macro. We create a token-specific ending macro which is blank for warnings that don't exist for the current compiler.

content.raw:
note also that clang defines `__GNUC__`, so if we want to detect clang it needs to be first in this list

it seems like this warning suppression system is a bit half-baked, probably should have had a separate pull request or design doc for it
content.html:
note also that clang defines __GNUC__, so if we want to detect clang it needs to be first in this list

it seems like this warning suppression system is a bit half-baked, probably should have had a separate pull request or design doc for it

content.raw:
I've attempted to suppress it using command line arguments for `ign-msgs`, but that attempt failed. [There seem to be cases where the warning refuses to be suppressed](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/8598354/why-is-msvc10-ignoring-my-pragma-warningdisable-4251), so there seems to be a possibility that we're stuck with that warning, short of some drastic measures.

Edit: That said, yes, I will attempt to suppress it.
content.html:
I've attempted to suppress it using command line arguments for ign-msgs, but that attempt failed. There seem to be cases where the warning refuses to be suppressed, so there seems to be a possibility that we're stuck with that warning, short of some drastic measures.

Edit: That said, yes, I will attempt to suppress it.

pull_request.title: Refactoring the cmake scripts to use ignition-cmake

pullrequest.title: Refactoring the cmake scripts to use ignition-cmake

content.raw:
This is an irritating idiom of Windows where member fields that use template arguments do not automatically get exported, despite the visibility of the class that contains them.

[A list of possible solutions is described here](https://stackoverflow.com/a/22054743).

If all of these member variables are private (like our PIMPL `std::unique_ptr`s), then I'd suggest we just suppress the message. I could pull the platform-independent warning suppression feature out of the existing plugin PRs and put it into its own PR, and that should help with this concern.

For the member variables that aren't `std::unique_ptr`, we should probably consider tucking them away behind a PIMPL, unless there's some compelling reason that we can't or shouldn't.
content.html:
This is an irritating idiom of Windows where member fields that use template arguments do not automatically get exported, despite the visibility of the class that contains them.

A list of possible solutions is described here.

If all of these member variables are private (like our PIMPL std::unique_ptrs), then I'd suggest we just suppress the message. I could pull the platform-independent warning suppression feature out of the existing plugin PRs and put it into its own PR, and that should help with this concern.

For the member variables that aren't std::unique_ptr, we should probably consider tucking them away behind a PIMPL, unless there's some compelling reason that we can't or shouldn't.

content.raw:
I've fixed a few more windows warnings in b828ce6  and 7ff5fa1 

the [only ones remaining](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_common-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/345/warningsResult/) are C4251: "<std::string, std::unique_ptr, std::shared_ptr> needs to have dll-interface to be used by clients of class X"

any ideas @mxgrey ?
content.html:
I've fixed a few more windows warnings in b828ce6 and 7ff5fa1

the only ones remaining are C4251: "<std::string, std::unique_ptr, std::shared_ptr> needs to have dll-interface to be used by clients of class X"

any ideas @mxgrey ?
